occurrences.line_text: Such an huge stroke, that it of sence distraught her:
For neuer had she suffred such despight.
Who yesterday droue vs to such distresse,
Such is the crueltie of womenkynd,
So great her pride, that she such basenesse much abhord.
That for such good him recompence with ill?
Bound vnto me, but not with such hard bands
For such your kind regard, I can but rest your detter.
Can yeeld great thankes for such her curtesie,
He wold by all good means he might, deserue such grace.
Bereaue it thence: such blot his honour blemish should.
Such was this Ladies fit, in her loues fond accusing.
But when she had with such vnquiet fits
Least any more such practise should proceede.
Such was the Goddesse; whom when Britomart
Such is the powre of that same fruit, that nought
At such a chaunge, and ioyed to behold
Did closely harbour such a iealous guest)
For high disdaine of such indignity,
Which they now hackt & hewd, as if such vse they hated,
Such wondrous powre hath wemens faire aspect,
Such was the furie of these head-strong steeds,
To tempt such steps, where footing was so ill:
Besides a thousand more of such, as sings
Those two strange knights such homage to her make,
And with sharpe reasons rang her such a pele,
Such be the meede of all, that by such mene
Such be the meede of all, that by such mene
With such his chearefull speaches he doth wield
From hand to hand, and with such nimblesse sly
Least by such slight he were vnwares deceiued;
The more t'aggrate his God with such his blouddy guize.
Such loathly matter were small lust to speake, or thinke.
That it to such a streight mote you constraine)
Fie on such forgerie (said Artegall)
And tell him that not for such slaughters sake
Most squalid garments, fit for such a day,
Such was Irenas countenance, such her case,
Such was Irenas countenance, such her case,
But with such force and furie violent,
He will not bide the daunger of such dread,
And with such monstrous poise adowne descended,
And all such persons, as did late maintayne
Meat fit for such a monsters monsterous dyeat.
Such were these Hags, and so vnhandsome drest:
And sprinckled with such sweet variety,
Such secret comfort, and such heauenly pleasures,
Such secret comfort, and such heauenly pleasures,
That you into such perils presently doth call?
Sayd Artegall, I such a Beast did see,
Such was the fury of Sir Calidore,
And made such piteous mourning therewithall,
His stroke redoubled with such might and maine,
Great skill it is such duties timely to bestow.
And gan to blame him for such cruelty
Tooke in foule scorne, that I such fault did find,
Well may I certes such an one thee read,
In gentle thewes, and such like seemely leres.
Such be our ioyes, which in these forrests grow:
The noble ympe of such new seruice fayne,
Such is the weakenesse of all mortall hope;
If I would beare behinde a burden of such scorne.
That should to me such curtesie afford,
To be the man, that with such scornefull pryde
Such chaunces oft exceed all humaine thought:
Such was the state of this most courteous knight
Saue such as sudden rage him lent to smite,
Such were this Ladies pangs and dolorous assay.
In such a saluage wight, of brutish kynd,
With such faire words she did their heate asswage,
Not with such forged showes, as fitter beene
Yet was their fare but homely, such as hee
Such as it was, ne did of want complaine,
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
Such were the wounds, the which that Blatant Beast
And being such, were now much more increast,
To goe about to salue such kynd of sore,
In a great tempest; that in such distresse,
And eke his Dame him seeing in such guize,
He for such basenesse shamefully him shent,
To shew such faintnesse and foule cowardize,
Or to allure such fondlings, whom she trayned
Whether such grace were giuen her by kynd,
By such discourteous deeds discouering his base kind.
The Prince much mused at such villenie,
T'aduize him better, then by such a traine
Would not be tempted to such villenie,
That such proud looks would make her praysed more;
Through such her stubborne stifnesse, and hard hart,
Did boast her beautie had such soueraine might,
Met her in such misseeming foule array;
As such a Lady so to beate and bruse;
But to him stepping, such a stroke him lent,
Beheld two such, of two such villaines thrall,
Beheld two such, of two such villaines thrall,
The which descended with such dreadfull sway,
With such huge strokes, approued oft in fight,
So huge a burden on such broken geare,
Would for it selfe redresse, and punish such despights.
This bottle thus before you with such toile,
As if such pride the other could apall;
As her to leaue in such a piteous plight.
For ioy of such good hap by heauenly grace.
For such a dismall deed, their guilt to hyde:
Of whom he makes such hauocke and such hew,
Of whom he makes such hauocke and such hew,
If such a beast they saw, which he had thether brought.
They answer'd him, that no such beast they saw,
But if that such there were (as none they kend)
Such homely what, as serues the simple clowne,
And wish my lot were plast in such felicitie.
And to great ones such follies doe forgiue,
Me no such cares nor combrous thoughts offend,
There I beheld such vainenesse, as I neuer thought.
For they to each such fortune doe diffuse,
With such queint vsage, fit for Queenes and Kings,
Ne euer had such knightly seruice seene,
Of such false blisse, as there is set for stales,
Such was the beauty of this goodly band,
Such were those Goddesses, which ye did see;
All which she with such courtesie doth grace,
In such discourses they together spent
With such regard his sences rauished,
Where with such damned fiends she should in darknesse dwell.
And by such trafficke after gaines to hunt,
Boldly him bad such iniurie forbeare;
Such was the conflict of those cruell Brigants there.
The sober mother seeing such her mood,
For other none such passion can contriue
In which such spoile, such hauocke, and such theft
In which such spoile, such hauocke, and such theft
In which such spoile, such hauocke, and such theft
Such was the fury of this hellish Beast,
And all such persons, as he earst did wrong,
That ay thereof her babes might sucke their fill;
Gan sucke this vitall aire into his brest,
And through his humid eyes did sucke his spright,
That she may sucke their life, and drinke their blood,
Then crauing sucke, and then the sucke refusing.
Then crauing sucke, and then the sucke refusing.
And sucked vp their dying mothers blood,
As other wemens babes, they sucked vitall blood.
And suckes the bloud, which from my hart doth bleed.
Sucking vpon her poisonous dugs, each one
Sucking the seas into his entralles deepe,
And there out sucking venime to her parts entyre.
Into her mouth they crept, and suddain all were gone.
And voide his course: at which so suddain case
Least suddaine mischiefe ye too rash prouoke:
With suddaine feare her pitcher downe she threw,
But suddaine catching hold, did her dismay
Encountring fierce, him suddaine doth surprize,
A ramping Lyon rushed suddainly,
And said, Deare dame, your suddein ouerthrow
And with that suddein horror could no member moue.
Suddein vpriseth from her stately place
His suddein eye, flaming with wrathfull fyre,
That suddein cold did runne through euery vaine,
And staggering steps, to weet, what suddein stowre
Yet forst, at last he made through silence suddein breach.
And all with suddein indignation fraight,
Was suddein vanished out of his sight:
Vnto the bush her eye did suddein glaunce,
With suddein fury all the fertile plaine,
When suddein vp the villein ouerthrowne,
That suddein forth they on them rusht, and threw
Through suddein feare and ghastly drerihed,
Which suddein fit, and halfe extatick stoure
Her former sorrow into suddein wrath,
That suddein change she strange aduenture thought.
Thereat was suddein strooke with great astonishment.
Who soone as she beheld that suddein stound,
As he that striues to stop a suddein flood,
And suddein parture of faire Florimell,
Stood gazing, as if suddein great affright
That seeke a Lady,---There he suddein staid,
The day with cloudes was suddeine ouercast,
That suddeine horror to faint harts did show;
Before that shield did fade, and suddeine fall:
And all his senses were with suddeine dread dismayd.
The knight much wondred at his suddeine wit,
The goddesse heard, and suddeine where she sate,
Which suddeine horrour and confused cry,
Suddeine they see from midst of all the Maine,
For not of nought these suddeine ghastly feares
Into a cleare Carnation suddeine dyde;
Therewith all suddeinly he seemd enraged,
Suddeinly out of his delightfull dreame
When suddeinly a grosse fog ouer spred
Suddeinly an innumerable flight
Then suddeinly both would themselues vnhele,
All suddeinly abasht she chaunged hew,
Nor seeme too suddeinly him to inuade:
At suddeinnesse of that vnwarie sight,
Who with the sudden stroke astonisht sore,
To weeten what that sudden clamour ment;
Wonder it is that sudden change to see:
When all men saw this sudden change of things,
To weet what sudden tidings was befeld:
And poureth forth a sudden shoure of raine,
For sudden ioy, and secret feare withall,
That sudden newes had made into his spright;
Long wayted, saw his sudden desolation,
And through her eyes like sudden lightning flashed,
And eke her selfe through sudden strange affright,
Saue such as sudden rage him lent to smite,
She sudden was reuiued therewithall,
All suddenly about his body wound,
Resolv'd in minde all suddenly to win,
Whom suddenly he wakes with fearefull frights,
All in amaze he suddenly vp start
When suddenly that warriour gan abace
The charme fulfild, dead suddenly he downe did sincke.
Where Guyon lay in traunce, when suddenly
All suddenly out of the thickest brush,
All suddenly with mortall stroke astownd,
All suddenly dim woxe the dampish ayre,
Like as a ship, whose Lodestarre suddenly
All suddenly a stormy whirlwind blew
All suddenly they both vpstarted light,
All suddenly they heard a troublous noyes,
Then suddenly as if their hearts did faile,
Or as if one him suddenly did call.
Yet durst he not make loue so suddenly,
When suddenly behind her backe she heard
Ne former strength returne so suddenly,
All suddenly, ere one can looke aside,
He suddenly his net vpon her threw,
My loues owne part to leaue so suddenly,
Like one that from his dreame is waked suddenlye.
And sude and sought with all the seruice dew:
To Proteus selfe to sue for her discharge:
How shall I quite the paines, ye suffer for my sake?
That all these sorrowes suffer for my sake,
He cast to suffer him no more respire,
Besought that Damzell suffer him depart,
Ne would he suffer Sleepe once thither-ward
Whiles thus we suffer this same dotard old,
Ne doth he suffer her, nor night, nor day,
Ne none can suffer to approchen neare:
And wonne her will to suffer him depart;
But ioy that for his sake I suffer prisonment.
And rather then his loue should suffer paine,
Ne lesse did Talus suffer sleepe to seaze
He would not suffer her alone to fare,
Ne would him suffer once to shrinke asyde,
Or suffer her out of her sleepe to wake,
But hasty heat tempring with sufferance wise,
With sober words, that sufferance desired,
He through long sufferance growing now more great,
The Prince, with patience and sufferaunce sly
With sufferaunce soft, which rigour can abate,
T'enure them selues to sufferaunce thereby
Sought through the world, and suffered so much ill,
And suffered them to passen quietly:
But suffered him to passe, all were she loth;
Ere rest he found. Much there he suffered,
Whiles that from heauen he suffered exile.
After long sorrowes suffered whyleare,
Ne suffereth it vncomely idlenesse,
Ne suffereth it thought of vngentlenesse,
For suffering such abuse, as knighhood shamed,
Not suffering the least twinckling sleepe to start
Suffers her selfe through sleepe beguild to bee,
Suffice it heare by signes to vnderstand
Ne him sufficeth all the wrong and ill,
Vnto such blisse? sufficient were that hire
For that himselfe thereto did want sufficient might.
Most wretched wight, whom nothing might suffise,
All these may not suffise, there shall to thee
Vntroubled Nature doth her selfe suffise,
Suffise it then, thou Money God (quoth hee)
What may suffise, to be for meede repayd
Suffise, that I haue done my dew in place.
Time and suffised fates to former kynd
Of meates and drinkes their appetites suffiz'd,
But being well suffiz'd, them rested faine.
But soone through suff'rance grow to fearefull end;
Till seeing them through suffrance hartned more,
Had giuen them, whose griefe through suffraunce sore increast.
Then home he suffred her for to retire,
And suffred not in wrath his hastie steps to stray.
And suffred not their blowes to byte him nere
Who suffred not his wandring feet to slide.
But the Blacke Palmer suffred still to stond,
Ne suffred them to rise or greater grow,
Ne suffred lust his safetie to betray;
Below the earth, might suffred be to stay:
And suffred rash Pyrrochles wast his idle might.
Ne suffred them to perish through long eld,
Ne suffred storme nor frost on them to fall,
Of that sweet place, yet suffred no delight
For neuer man he suffred by that same
Ne suffred she the Middayes scorching powre,
But suffred her so carelesly disguized
And suffred beasts her body to deflowre:
And neuer suffred her to be at rest:
Is suffred here to enter, but he seeme
Suffred, these seuen monethes day in secret den
Ne suffred sleepe to settle in his brest.
But suffred that same Dwarfe me to her dongeon driue.
And suffred all his secret marke to see:
But seeming to haue suffred mickle wrong,
But suffred cruell shipwracke by the way.
For neuer had she suffred such despight.
Ne suffred slothfull sleepe her eyelids to oppresse.
She suffred, yet at length she did requight,
Could euer loose, but suffred deadly doole.
And onely suffred him this wretched life to liue.
Yet nathemore him suffred to arize;
Then suffred he Disdaine vp to arise,
That day nor night he suffred him to rest,
Ne day nor night he suffred her to rest,
Why suffredst thou thy Nephewes deare to fall
How suffrest thou such shamefull cruelty,
Ne suffreth he resort of liuing wight
Suffring my hand against my heart to stray:
So suffring him to rise, he made him sweare
And scarsely suffring her infestred wound,
Wiping the teares from her suffused eyes,
The sugred licour through his melting lips:
With sugred words and gentle blandishment,
Thenceforth the suit of earthly conquest shonne,
And honours suit my vowed dayes do spend,
Whom he had long time sought with fruitlesse suit:
He mote surcease his suit, and lose the hope
After long suit and weary seruicis,
The which, for all the suit I could propound,
His former suit, and from them fled apace;
With humblest suit that he imagine mot,
And with meeke seruice and much suit did lay
Made humble suit vnto his Maiestie,
How earnest suit she earst for him had made
Which wont doe suit and seruice to his might;
Nor hold from suite of his auowed quest,
Vnto his soueraine Queene her suite for to commend.
Musing full sadly in his sullein mind;
That sullein Saturne euer weend to loue?
Yet loue is sullein, and Saturnlike seene,
He looking lompish and full sullein sad,
With windy Nitre and quick Sulphur fraught,
A cloud of smoothering smoke and sulphur seare
With smoake and sulphure hiding all the place,
As smoke and sulphure mingled with confused strife.
And stinking Sulphure, that with griesly hate
A direfull stench of smoke and sulphure mixt
Breathing out clouds of sulphure fowle and blacke,
Like as the shining skie in summers night,
Lay hid: thereof she countlesse summes did reare,
He which doth summon louers to Loues iudgement hall.
Such endlesse richesse, and so sumptuous shew;
Home is he brought, and laid in sumptuous bed:
In sumptuous tire she ioyd her selfe to prancke,
Therein to shrowd her sumptuous Belamoure,
In sumptuous bed she made him to be layd,
But for to tell the sumptuous aray
They greatly wondred, whence so sumptuous guize
Whom they found sitting on a sumptuous bed,
Where they were serued with all sumptuous fare,
And by the rest did set in sumptuous chaire,
Gay girlonds, from the Sun their forheads faire to shade.
Of the sunbeames in moyst complexion,
In sun-bright armes, and battailous array:
His sunbroad shield about his wrest he bond,
His speare amids her sun-broad shield arriued;
Like as the sunburnt Indians do aray
His sad dull eyes deepe sunck in hollow pits,
They on this rock are rent, and sunck in helplesse wawes.
And softly sunck into her molten hart;
And suncke so deepe into their boyling brests,
Beene suncke, of whom no memorie did stay:
And quite a sunder broke. Forth flowed fresh
Of his huge taile he quite a sunder cleft,
That hart of flint a sunder could haue rift:
Which hewing quite a sunder, further way
Which fled a sunder, and him fell before,
Yet nathemore the steele a sunder riued,
It forth to wrest, the staffe a sunder brake,
Therewith a sunder in the midst it brast,
But riued were like rotten wood a sunder,
But it would loose, or else a sunder teare.
And rend a sunder quite, if he thereto list striue.
A sunder, yet not euer in one place,
And with their troupes did far a sunder cast:
As if his lungs and lites were nigh a sunder brast.
Ye did so streightly them a sunder keepe,
And from the head the body sundred quight.
That each of them from other sundred were,
All which long sundred, doe at last accord
Since which, with sundrie spoiles she hath beene ransacked.
So diuersely each one did sundrie doubts deuise.
And each his sundrie sheepe with seuerall care
Of sundrie things he purpose gan to faine;
Of sundry shapes, yet all ill fauored:
His Magick bookes and artes of sundry kindes,
Wherein the cherefull birds of sundry kind
Thus as they gan of sundry things deuise,
By certaine signes here set in sundry place
Therein three sisters dwelt of sundry sort,
These three in these three roomes did sundry dwell,
With sundry colours, in the which were writ
Of this sad Realme, cut into sundry shaires
That did her selfe in sundry parts diuide,
Yet oft annoyd with sundry bordragings
With mightie deedes their sundry gouernments;
The other fiue, fiue sundry wayes he set,
Some land-marke seem'd to be, or signe of sundry way.
Of sundry things faire purpose gan to find,
Their sundry kings to do their homage seuerall.
So beene they three three sundry wayes ybent.
And euery sort is in a sundry bed
To change her hew, and sundry formes to don,
And wings it had with sundry colours dight,
More sundry colours, then the proud Pauone
By sundry meanes thereto she prickt him forth,
And by the way she sundry purpose found
Cast into sundry shapes by wondrous skill,
And shadie seates, and sundry flowring bankes,
And all their sundry kinds, and all their hid abodes.
Both thirty sorts of fish, and thirty sundry streames.
A Chapelet of sundry flowers she wore,
And gan of sundry newes his store to tell,
And sundry battels, which she hath atchieued
As sundry chaunge her seemed best to ease.
(As often falles) of sundry things did commen.
Oftimes their sundry powres they did employ,
Of sundry flowres, with silken ribbands tyde,
Of sundry things, as fell, to worke delay;
Whose sundry parts were here too long to tell:
Till some, which did the sundry prisoners knowe,
Tho further asking her of sundry things,
Of sundry kindes, and sundry quality;
Of sundry kindes, and sundry quality;
And to the Maydens sounding tymbrels sung
The whiles one sung a song of loue and iollity.
Sometimes she sung, as loud as larke in aire,
All which together sung full chearefully
All which the sad effects of discord sung:
Wayting when as the Antheme should be sung on hye.
Which in their lower braunches sung aloud;
As he hath sung of thee in all his dayes,
Thrise he her reard, and thrise she sunke againe,
Of the young Damzell sunke, that great desire
Soone as the infants sunlike shield they saw,
The Sunne that measures heauen all day long,
Then with the Sunne take Sir, your timely rest,
And scorching Sunne does dry my secret vaines:
But since faire Sunne hath sperst that lowring clowd,
Could not endure th'vnwonted sunne to view;
The golden Sunne his glistring head gan shew,
She would commaund the hastie Sunne to stay,
As Eagles eye, that can behold the Sunne:
In heauenly Registers aboue the Sunne,
As morning Sunne her beames dispredden cleare,
Most ioyous man, on whom the shining Sunne,
Where Mammon earst did sunne his threasury:
Now hath the Sunne with his lamp-burning light,
Ne vnder Sunne, that shines so wide and faire,
From the vprising to the setting Sunne,
She turned her contrarie to the Sunne,
Both Sunne and Moone, and make them him obay:
More hidden are, then Sunne in cloudy vele;
There shall a Rauen far from rising Sunne,
A fairer wight did neuer Sunne behold,
Belphoebe was her name, as faire as Phoebus sunne.
When the bright sunne his beams thereon doth beat;
Informed in the mud, on which the Sunne hath shynd.
On the bright Sunne vnwares, doth soone withdraw
But sith the Sunne now ginnes to slake his beames,
Who bold to guide the charet of the Sunne,
Which to his Critias, shaded oft from sunne,
Till euening, that the Sunne gan downward bend.
Or else some woodman shrowded there from scorching sunne.
Faire lawnds, to take the sunne in season dew;
The sunne at length his ioyous face doth cleare:
From euery coast and countrie vnder sunne:
Which bore the Sunne brode blazed in a golden field.
Like as Osyris signifies the Sunne.
As the bright sunne, what time his fierie teme
Begins to turne, and sunne to shine more bright,
Of the bright mettall, shyning like Sunne rayes;
At last about the setting of the Sunne,
Sunne of the world, great glory of the sky,
Like to a flowre, that feeles no heate of sunne,
To see the hatefull sunne, that he might tell
The sunne-beames bright vpon her body playd,
Vpon his sunne-bright shield, and gript it fast withall.
That since the time they first tooke the Sunnes hight,
As when two sunnes appeare in the azure skye,
The Sunnes bright wayne to Phaetons decay,
Of that sunne-shine, that makes them looke askew.
Sunning his threasure hore:
And a rich throne, as bright as sunny day,
Who when she saw Duessa sunny bright,
And face all tand with scorching sunny ray,
So faire a creature yet saw neuer sunny day.
Like sunny beames threw from her Christall face,
Where stretcht he lay vpon the sunny side
One sitting idle on a sunny bancke,
